item.title: A Guide to the Good Life - page 161
item.author: Kyle Tress
item.description: In particular, says Seneca, we need to remember that in some case, the person at whom we are angry in fact helped us; in such cases, what angers us is that he didn’t help us more.

item.title: A Guide to the Good Life
item.author: Kyle Tress

item.title: How should I prepare for Skeleton School?
item.author: Kyle Tress
item.description: There is no preparation necessary for Skeleton School. You don’t need to learn how to drive beforehand – you can’t. You can only learn that aspect of the sport through experience, which comes with taking runs down the track. Skeleton School is mostly an opportunity to see if you really enjoy the sport. It looks fun on TV, but there have been many people who thought the same thing only to arrive in Lake Placid, take a run, and leave that same day never to return. Just show up, listen to the coaches, and see if you like it.

item.title: The Art of Learning - page 192
item.author: Kyle Tress
item.description: I hated the fact that I had traveled all the way to Taiwan and had not even given myself a chance to compete. Some serious adjustments were called for.

item.title: The Art of Learning - page 187
item.author: Kyle Tress
item.description: The real power of incremental growth comes to bear when we truly are like water, steadily carving stone. We just keep on flowing when everything is on the line.

item.title: The Art of Learning - page 179
item.author: Kyle Tress
item.description: Players who are able to relax in brief moments of inactivity are almost always the ones who end up coming through when the game is on the line.

item.title: The Art of Learning - page 172
item.author: Kyle Tress
item.description: IN competition, the dynamic is often painfully transparent. If one player is serenely present while the other is being ripped apart by internal issues, the outcome is already clear.

item.title: The Art of Learning - page 137
item.author: Kyle Tress
item.description: For much of this book I have described my vision of the road to mastery — you start with the fundamentals, get a solid foundation fueled by understanding the principles of your discipline, then you expand and refine your repetoire, guided by your individual predispositions, while keeping in touch, however abstractly, with what you feel to be the essential core of the art.

item.title: The Art of Learning - page 123
item.author: Kyle Tress
item.description: The fact is that when there is intense comptiton, those who succeed have slightly more honed skills than the rest. It is rarely a mysterious technique that drives us to the top, but rather a profound mastery of what may well be a basic skill set.

item.title: Minimalism
item.author: Kyle Tress
item.description: Minimalism isn’t about owning less stuff. It’s about owning the right amount of the right stuff.

item.title: Bill Murray
item.author: Kyle Tress
item.description:
Bill Murray, on his penchant for showing up unannounced at odd places:

I think the only reason I’ve had the career life that I’ve had is that someone told me some secrets early on about living. You can do the very best you can when you’re very, very relaxed, no matter what it is or what your job is, the more relaxed you are the better you are. That’s sort of why I got into acting. I realized the more fun I had, the better I did it. And I thought, that’s a job I could be proud of. It’s changed my life learning that, and it’s made me better at what I do.

item.title: The Superintelligence Reading Group
item.author: Kyle Tress
item.description: I’ve signed up for the Superintelligence reading group, hosted by the Machine Intelligence Research Institute. The group will meet virtually once a week to discuss readings on Nick Bostrom’s new book, Superintelligence: Paths, Dangers, Strategies. As I’ve mentioned before, artificial intelligence is one of my favorite topics and likely one of the most important problems of the 21st century.

item.title: absolute-strength
item.author: Kyle Tress
item.description:
I"m starting an absolute strength block tomorrow. It’s my favorite training block of the summer because:

  • 3x3.
  • 90-97.5% intensity.
  • week off at the end
  • No household chores allowed.

It’s mostly just the last one.

item.title: Photo with President Obama
item.author: Kyle Tress
item.description: Here’s a great photo from when I met President Barack Obama and the First Lady at The White House in April.

item.title: Video on How to eat sushi
item.author: Kyle Tress
item.description: I enjoyed this video on How to eat sushi, particularly tip #3.

item.title: r/sliding
item.author: Kyle Tress
item.description:
I created the r/sliding subreddit on reddit. I hope to turn it into a good resource for potential athletes and fans of the sliding sports.

This is just an excerpt so I’m curious how long it has to be before the body gets truncated, and also, what that actually looks like. Not long enough yet! How much longer do you think it has to be? Im guessing anywhere from 50 to 100 words. This has to be approaching that very soon.

item.title: Are we living in a computer simulation?
item.author: Kyle Tress
item.description: I really liked this video on the Simulation Theory.
